Award.AwardTitle: Children's Use of Visual Summary-Statistics for Material Perception

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Adults are experts at using visual input to recognize objects, like tools, animals, books, or other common items, and at recognizing materials, like cloth, wood, or plastic. While we know a great deal about how children learn to recognize objects, we know very little about how they learn to recognize materials. This project will help us understand how children's abilities to categorize real-world materials change during childhood, and will establish what information children use for recognition as they get older. Understanding material categorization may illuminate many similar tasks that depend on the same kinds of visual computations. Additional work in this domain will likely reveal important links between material categorization and a wide range of other processes including visual search and visual attention. The abilities that probably contribute to material recognition, such as texture perception, continue to develop until about 10 years of age, but at present, we do not know what is changing. What mechanisms allow children to recognize materials at different ages?

This project will focus on understanding how children at different ages use pure texture information and global image patterns to recognize materials. A sophisticated computer graphics model will make it possible to use images that represent real textures to create stimulus displays that represent artificial textures; the use of artificial textures that have some information missing and other information intact will reveal what features 5- to 10-year-old children rely upon to recognize materials. Children in these experiments will be asked to categorize presented images by assigning labels to them using a touchscreen interface (naming images as "Wood," "Stone," or "Plastic"), or will be asked to indicate which of several target images matches a sample image according to the material pictured in the images. Manipulating image appearance using a texture synthesis algorithm will permit evaluation of how children's categorization and matching of natural materials is affected by what information is available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we explored how children look at real-world materials like wood, plastic, and metal, and recognize what they are based on the way that they look. To be more specific, we wanted to know if children might use different information than adults to make decisions about materials and how that may change between the ages of 5 and 10 years old. We found out that children do use different information than adults to make these decisions: Unlike adults, who use small and large parts of a picture to decide what something is made of, children seem to mostly use small details to make the same decisions. This means that they make more mistakes than adults and different mistakes, too. Some materials end up being harder to recognize than others, and recognizing materials under different conditions (like a blurry image) can be harder, too. We think this means that children's vision may be different than adults' in specific ways that could affect the way they do many different tasks. Our experiments helped us learn more about how to describe the way children's vision develops, in particular with regard to how they look at textures and use them to make decisions about what things are made of.

Besides providing opportunities for students in our lab to learn more about research, our project also helped us work with students outside of our university. Some of these students were middle-schoolers that we worked with at a summer camp at our institution, and others were Native American students that we worked with in their communities. In both cases, we came up with hands-on lessons about vision science that introduced these students to some of the basic principles of how our eyes and our brains work together to help us understand what we see. We're excited to continue working with students in our community and beyond to share our love of vision science, and this project helped support us while we developed learning experiences for all ages.
